data.title: Add option to let new windows cascade when set to inherit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new window from an existing window.

This is related to: New windows should get the size of the previous active window #10864. It's great that the new setting ("window.newWindowDimensions": "inherit") was added to preserve the window size.

But, the new window overlaps exactly on the existing window. It might be a little bit confusing. A user may think that the previous window was closed. Or, was replaced by a new one. I think it should follow the behavior of widely used applications such as Windows Explorer or Firefox, both of which cascade the new window a little bit so as to differentiate it with the previous one.

Probably a new configuration setting such as, "window.newWindowPosition" with options, "same" and "cascade" could be added.

It's a feature request. No hurry.

Thanks.

data.title: First save of a file takes too long

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Version 1511, Build 10586.545)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file.
2. Type some code in it.
3. Save the file.

It takes 5 seconds on an average for the file name to appear on the tab and syntax highlighting to show if the language was not selected already. I have observed this behavior for about a month now. It is really annoying.

I tried the same steps with Notepad++, it saves and highlights in an instant. So, it's not a performance issue of my machine / OS.

Thanks.

data.title: Creating a new folder in open dialog needs a manual refresh (like F5) to show up
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Version 1511, Build 10586.545)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code.
2. From File menu, select "Open File" (or "Open Folder", or "Save As").
3. Try to create a new folder by clicking "New Folder".
4. The new folder does not show up.
5. Press F5 to refresh.
6. The new folder shows up.
7. Now, try to rename the folder.
8. When you hit enter after renaming the folder, it still shows as "New Folder".
9. Hit F5.
10. Now, it shows as the renamed folder.

It may be a bug in the common library being used for development for Microsoft products. I verified using Firefox and Notepad. In Firefox, the behavior is alright. I can create new folder and rename it without having to refresh. But, in Notepad, the above mentioned issue is present.

Probably, the developers/maintainers of this project know best where to forward this issue in case it needs to be fixed by some other team at Microsoft.

Thanks.

data.title: Please support skipfiles and entries starting with '!'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.12

When using component-based development with node (multiple of my own npm packages in play) and when debugging a project, it is very useful to be able to skip all node_modules EXCEPT one's own npm's (see example below). Unfortunately, when trying to do so, I get a msg "skipFiles entries starting with '!' aren't supported and will be ignored."

```
        "skipFiles": [
	       "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/**/*.js",
                "!${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/my-own-module**/*.js"
	 ],
```

data.title: Force quit with the ability to revert changes silently
data.body:
With Vim keybinding extensions, there is a command :q! that is a force quit.

When you execute this command it quits, without prompting, and without storing any changes. This is what differentiates it from hotexit, all changes should be **reverted**.

All prompts should be suppressed and the editor should be closed right away.

Currently there is nothing in the API to allow us to do this 

```:q! to quit without saving (short for :quit!)```

Over at VSCodeVim this is one of our highest rated issues:
https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/979

data.title: Referencing variables in settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
### Referencing variables in settings

- VSCode Version:
```
Version 1.10.0-insider
Commit 40fecfaa77f01672e8a147be71f6f7ccb9cf8a12
Date 2017-02-27T14:13:35.653Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```

As of the current insider build of VS Code, I don't see a way of referencing the values of previously refined variables. For example, in my settings:
```json
  // Controls the wrapping column of the editor when `editor.wordWrap` is 'wordWrapColumn' or 'bounded'.
  "editor.wordWrapColumn": 80,

  // Width to word-wrap to when using gq.
  "vim.textwidth": 80,
```
I want to keep the values of both the variables consistent. It would be nice to have something like:
```json
"vim.textwidth": @"editor.wordWrapColumn",
```

Not sure if JSON has a standard way of referencing previous objects, but this would be a nice feature to have at least within VS Code. YAML doesn't support referencing directly either, but at least you can define node anchors and then reference them later.

data.title: firstLine in Language Requires Entire line to match
data.body:
From http://stackoverflow.com/questions/42498117/vscode-syntax-highlighting-for-custom-shebang

For a file such as:

```
#!/some/directory/envroot "ENVROOT/bin/python"
....
```

We currently do not recognize the file as python even though the internal python extension's `firstLine` contribution matches. The reason is that the entire first line has to match: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/base/common/mime.ts#L206

This seems inconsistent with how TextMate uses `firstLineMatch`, and some of our grammars use `firstLine` patterns that do not work well with this restriction, such as `extension/xml`:

```
"firstLine" : "(\\<\\?xml.*)|(\\<svg)|(\\<\\!doctype\\s+svg)",
```

which fails to match:

```
<svg>
...
</svg>
```

data.title: Fix Webview scroll position Preserving
data.body:
**Bug**
A regression since 1.9 caused the scroll preserve behavior of webviews to stop working in certain cases. There appears to be a race condition where `newFrame.contentDocument.body` does not exist when the scroll preserve code is called

**Fix**
Instead of using a timeout, update the scroll position when `DOMContentLoaded` is fired from the webview window

Fixes #21491

data.title: Phantom `git:/` virtual paths sometimes appear in Problems View
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (40fecfaa77f01672e8a147be71f6f7ccb9cf8a12, 2017-02-27T14:15:13.224Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

### Repro steps:
1. create new php file with an error - e.g. `a.php`
```php
<?php

function a () {
```
2. Open the problems view
3. Switch to a different tab, switch back
4. Notice that two problems appear in view
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/23384815/41978d3a-fd01-11e6-99f2-0dc88c179033.png)


### Additional notes:
* the folder is not under source control (I know the screenshot above shows that it is, but it was also broken before initializing the repo)
* I've also seen the issue appear for ESLint files as well, so it's not just PHP, although I haven't been able to find a small and consistent repro for this one (the following case *was* under source control, but still made no sense to me)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/23384842/63b32ca8-fd01-11e6-891c-d645131342cb.png)
* The issue cannot be reproduced when you launch from the latest bits in master `scripts/code.bat` (and I haven't seen any recent changes that would have addressed this issue)
* The issue doesn't appear to reproduce for all extensions (or at least not that I've seen)
* The issue does not reproduce in v1.9.1, so this is a regression.
* sometimes the errors linger after issue in the actual file is addressed, and sometimes they do not. 
* the phantom virtual file only appears for one file at a time unless the error lingers
* attempting to navigate to the phantom file yields a totally blank and un-editable file

data.title: Add when clauses for TypeScript command palette commands
data.body: Fixes #21522

data.title: [Debugger] Adding a Watch expression sends 'evaluate' command twice
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 
```
Version 1.9.1
Commit f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519
Date 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```
- OS Version:
Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
I am using the C# extension to reproduce this, but it should be visible from any debug adapter.

1. Use the C# Extension to debug a .NET Core console app with the following code:
```cs
using System;

namespace ConsoleApplication
{
    public class Program
    {
        public static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            int i=1;
            i++;
        } // BP Here
    }
}
```
2. Turn on debugger logging by adding the following block to launch.json launch configuration:
```
            "logging": {
                "traceResponse": true
            }
```
3. Set a breakpoint on the line indicated and start debugging
4. View the debug console to see tracing output
5. Evaluate `i++` in the Watch area

Expected: `i++` shows 2 in the watch expression (it is post decrement so it should return 2)
Actual: `i++` shows 3 in the watch expression, because it is being evaluated twice

This is also shown in the debugger log output:
```
C evaluate: {"expression":"i++","frameId":1000,"context":"watch"}
 R: {"success":true,"message":null,"request_seq":12,"command":"evaluate","body":{"result":"2","variablesReference":0,"type":"int"},"running":false,"refs":null,"seq":0,"type":"response"}
C evaluate: {"expression":"i++","frameId":1000,"context":"watch"}
 R: {"success":true,"message":null,"request_seq":13,"command":"evaluate","body":{"result":"3","variablesReference":0,"type":"int"},"running":false,"refs":null,"seq":0,"type":"response"}
C variables: {"variablesReference":1000}
 R: {"success":true,"message":null,"request_seq":14,"command":"variables","body":{"variables":[{"name":"args [string[]]","value":"{string[0]}","type":"string[]","variablesReference":0,"evaluateName":"args"},{"name":"i [int]","value":"2","type":"int","variablesReference":0,"evaluateName":"i"}]},"running":false,"refs":null,"seq":0,"type":"response"}

```

data.title: bump version for 1.11
Network: Left side explore folders don't always open

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.9.1
- OS Version: windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
Don't know how to reproduce this consistently.

I can be editing along and want to go to a folder in the Explorer on the left.
I hit the folder name with the mouse. The caret changes from pointing right to pointing down, but the subfolder do not open.  (see the 2 attached files, open and closed). 
![closed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16655822/23377813/f693ef68-fcf6-11e6-9d4e-8f7980caba9b.png)
Click on folder. It is still closed, but now looks like this:
![open](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16655822/23377812/f692e5e6-fcf6-11e6-8024-e3d5059cc749.png)

If I reload the folder and hit refresh, it seems to work
![correct](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16655822/23377901/32b22fa0-fcf7-11e6-99b4-3b70d9c0a5c4.png)
